content.description:
The route follows the central right facing corner system in the middle of the wall. There are a few spots where you can wander left or right making it a choose your own adventure. The climb is just shy of 70 meters and can be climbed in 1 or 2 pitches by building a gear belay at the top of the second grassy ledge. Some route finding and loose rock management required. Slightly run out in one section but easy climbing. Bolted belay at the top. From the top ledge it's a short scramble to the peak and you can descend back to the bottom via the regular gully route.



From the col on the Plaid Lake trail head north a few hundred meters then traverse left to the base of the slab. The face is easily visible from the main trail.

A double set of BD's #.75 - #3 and a selection of small cams and nuts

Good little route juste left of crawdaddy follow the dihedral and try to find good pro between loose block on the left side of the corner. Mainly 5.5 until the last 10meters where you can choose to finish in the face of follow the loose but very easy dihedral.
. A super fun broken finger size crack  is waiting for you with a little roof. Keep yourself some small piece for up there.



The dihedral juste left of crawdaddy. Which is mostly dirty and low angle

Finish at the bolt anchor of crawdaddy then walk down

WATCH FOR LOOSE BLOCK WITH ROPE

SR to 3
A low angle slab of quartzite on the west face of Mount Crawford. Pretty rock, easy climbing, low commitment and beautiful views.
